question: Mike was a pen pal with 5 people.  He stopped being penpals with 2 of them.  They each send 2 letters a week that are 5 pages long.  He responds in kind.  He can write a page every 6 minutes.  How many hours does he spend writing a week?
answer:
He is penpals with 5-2=<<5-2=3>>3 people
Thus he gets 3*2=<<3*2=6>>6 letters a week
So he writes 6*5=<<6*5=30>>30 pages a week
So he writes for 30*6=<<30*6=180>>180 minutes a week
So he writes 180/60=<<180/60=3>>3 hours a week
#### 3
question_annotated:
{name,Mike} was a pen pal with {n1,5} people. He stopped being penpals with {n2,2} of them. They each send {l,2} letters a week that are {p,5} pages long. He responds in kind. He can write a page every {t,6} minutes. On average, how many hours does {name,Mike} spend writing in a day?

#init:
- name = sample(names_male)
- $n1 = range(5, 15)
- $n2 = range(1, 5)
- $l = range(2, 5)
- $p = range(5, 12)
- $t = range(4, 15)

#conditions:
- n2 < n1
- is_int(((n1 - n2) * l * p * t) / 60)
- divides(((n1 - n2) * l * p * t) // 60, 7)

#answer: ((n1 - n2) * l * p * t) // 60 // 7
answer_annotated:
{name} is penpals with {n1}-{n2}=<<{n1}-{n2}={n1-n2}>>{n1-n2} people
Thus he gets {n1-n2}*{l}=<<{n1-n2}*{l}={(n1-n2)*l}>>{(n1-n2)*l} letters a week
So he writes {(n1-n2)*l}*{p}=<<{(n1-n2)*l}*{p}={((n1-n2)*l*p)}>>{((n1-n2)*l*p)} pages a week
So he writes for {((n1-n2)*l*p)}*{t}=<<{((n1-n2)*l*p)}*{t}={((n1-n2)*l*p*t)}>>{((n1-n2)*l*p*t)} minutes a week
So he writes {((n1-n2)*l*p*t)}/60=<<{((n1-n2)*l*p*t)}/60={((n1-n2)*l*p*t)//60}>>{((n1-n2)*l*p*t)//60} hours a week. 
To calculate the average per day we divide {((n1-n2)*l*p*t)//60} / 7 = {((n1-n2)*l*p*t)//60//7}
#### {((n1-n2)*l*p*t)//60//7}
